items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: River levels on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook remain high but are slowly dropping. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham and roads near Reybridge. The weather outlook currently shows dry weather for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Flooding remains possible.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. River levels along the River Churn remain high, particularly in Cerney Wick. The weather forecast is dry on Christmas and Boxing Day. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
High river levels have led to flooding of land close to the river. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue on the lower River Cherwell near Thrupp and Kidlington. The weather forecast is dry on Christmas and Boxing Day. River levels are falling slowly but we expect them to remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00, midday, on the 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
The flood risk remains.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue as river levels along the River Windrush remain high, particularly in Bourton on the Water, Witney, Standlake and Newbridge. The weather forecast is dry on Christmas and Boxing Day. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. 

Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00, midday, on the 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
High river levels have led to flooding of land close to the River Glyme. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue on the River Glyme at Woodstock. The river is now flowing within banks on the River Evenlode although water will remain in fields close to the river over the next few days. The weather forecast is dry on Christmas and Boxing Day. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days, particularly on the River Glyme.  

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. 

Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 12:00, midday, on the 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem, and Rodington. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message: River levels are still high but are falling slowly on the Lower Frome. Flooding may still be affecting low lying areas near to the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool, East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas. No significant rain is forecast for today or tomorrow and river levels are falling slowly. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 26 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message: River levels remain high. Flooding is possible on 25 December 2025. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: Water levels remain high on the Rivers Yeo and Parrett and surrounding moors. But with dry weather forecast for the days ahead. Low lying land and roads are expected to be most affected by flooding. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if the drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station exceeds 7.3m; the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m; Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and Muchelney to Drayton above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Refer to Somerset Council’s website for any local road closures. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. And we are pumping and operating the Parrett Relief Channel when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Derwent following recent rainfall. As a result, flooding is possible today, Thursday 25th December 2025.

Locations most affected will be local roads and low-lying land near rivers around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington.

Levels are expected to fall slowly over the next few days. We are monitoring the forecast and river levels and liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 8:00AM on Friday 26th December 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 21:30 and 23:00 on Thursday 25th December 2025. 
Locations impacted include the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads on or near the coast. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded . Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: River levels are falling but flooding is possible for Lower Rivers Tone and Parrett including West Moor, Hay Moor, Curry Moor, Stan Moor, Salt Moor and North Moor. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is falling slowly (currently 7.19m). Water is no longer entering Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway as this level has dropped below 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.37m. Cutts Road floods when the drain level at Currymoor pumping station is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to the latest gauge levels on Check for Flooding and Somerset Council’s website for information on road closures in the area. Dry weather is forecast for the next few days. We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels. Pumping has commenced at Currymoor and will continue as and when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High and rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Levels may continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may see levels continue to rise. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation . Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 30 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the 23rd December 2025 onwards 
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 30 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message: River levels are gradually falling but remain high due to the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Flooding could still affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. There is no significant rain forecast for today or tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message: High water levels are expected to cause flooding today 25 December 2025. Flooding may affect locations near the River Tone, Currymoor Main Drain (currently at 6.34m and falling), with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Cutts Road floods when the Currymoor Main Drain is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. River Parrett levels are being managed using the Parrett relief channel. Dry weather is forecast for the next few days. We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels. Pumping has commenced at Currymoor and will continue as and when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater
items.message: River levels remain high following recent rainfall, however we're expecting levels to gradually fall throughout today. Flooding is possible from the afternoon of Thursday 25th December 2025. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on the 26th December 2025 or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. items.message: Water levels remain high on the Rivers Yeo and Parrett and surrounding moors. But with dry weather forecast for the days ahead. Low lying land and roads are expected to be most affected by flooding, particularly around the A37 south and A303 south west of Ilchester, the Ilchester to Limington road and road to Ilchester Meads. There is also a risk of flooding around Hainbury Mill, Ilchester. Please refer to the latest gauge levels on Check for Flooding and Somerset Council’s website for information on road closures in the area. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. And we are pumping when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 26 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Hooke
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 

Flooding is expected from the 23rd December 2025 onwards 

Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Hooke, Toller Whelme and Toller Porcorum. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has risen to 165m, and is expected to rise over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, and roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. 

We are closely monitoring the situation . 

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 30 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 

Flooding is expected from 23rd December 2025 onwards 

Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbounre Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterborne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterborne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 118m, and is expected to continue rising in next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, Roads may be damaged by floodwater. intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. 

We are closely monitoring the situation . 

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 30 December 2025 or as the situation changes.
